Content.Title: Math 100L: Lesson 12
Content.BodyCopy:
Flashcard Vocabulary

  • convenient (adj)
  • caution (n)
  • probably (adv)

Helpful Vocabulary

  • coefficient (n)
  • to figure out (v)
  • vice versa (adv)
  • cinch (n)
  • vast majority
  • shallow (adj)
  • to bet (v)
  • to handle (v)
  • extra (adj)
  • to apologize (v)
  • to let someone loose
  • entire (adj)
  • to skip (v)
  • integer (n)

Visit 1: Graphing Equations with Slope

Math 100L Lesson 12 PDF

Bring your math textbook to Visit #1 and Visit #2.


Read the following information to your Speaking Partner:

As you learn English, you will find yourself in conversations with others. There are many common phrases in English that will help you with your speaking skills.

Hesitating and Taking Time to Think

  • Hmm …
  • That's a good question.
  • Well …
  • Let’s see …
  • Let me think.
  • It depends.

Requesting Help

  • Could you help me, please?
  • Can you please help me _____ ?
  • Will you help me _____ ?
  • Would you please help me _____ ?
  • Would you mind _____ ?
  • Would you mind helping me?
  • Could you possibly help me out here?

Expressing Thanks

  • Thanks.
  • Thank you.
  • Thanks a lot.
  • Thank you very much.
  • I appreciate it.
  • Thanks for your time.
  • I appreciate your help.
  • I appreciate your kindness.
  • You’ve been very helpful.
  • That was really nice of you.

Responding to Thanks

  • You’re welcome.
  • No problem.
  • Glad to do it.
  • Don’t mention it.
  • It’s my pleasure.
  • It was nothing.
  • Any time.

Apologizing

  • I’m sorry.
  • I’m very sorry.
  • I’m terribly sorry.
  • Excuse me.
  • Pardon me.
  • I apologize.
  • My apologies.

Discussion Questions

  1. Have you heard most of these phrases before?
  2. Which ones are the most common?
  3. Which phrases does your speaking partner use most often?
  4. Which ones are you most comfortable with?
  5. Share an experience in which you expressed thanks to someone. How did that person respond?
  6. Share an experience in which someone thanked you for doing something. How did you respond?
  7. What is your favorite phrase for responding to thanks?
  8. What is your speaking partner’s favorite phrase for apologizing?


Graphing Equations with Slope

This week you will learn how to find the slope of a line once you have an equation. It is possible to get the slope from a couple of points without actually figuring it out. Read the following information to your Speaking Partner.

The two common forms of finding slope from an equation are (1) the standard form, and (2) the slope-intercept form.

Standard FormSlope-Intercept Form
Format
  • Written in the form Ax + By = C, where A, B, and C are integers (usually).
  • Intercepts are found by putting 0 in for either x or y, so each is relatively easily found as (0, C/B) and (C/A, 0).
  • Slope is always m = –A/B.
  • Written in the form y = mx + b.
  • m is the slope without any adjustment.
  • (0, b) is the y-intercept.
Advantages
  • It has no fractions.
  • Both x- and y-intercepts have some amount of calculation.
  • Slope is most easily found.
  • Y-intercept is most easily found.
  • Prepares you for function f(x) notation.
Disadvantages
  • Minor calculations for y-intercept.
  • Remembering to put the negative sign on the slope.
  • Fractions are often part of the equation.

They are simply two different ways to write the same equation. Every point that works in one will work in the other.

Do the following exercises with your Speaking Partner:

  1. Graph the following lines, and label the x- and y-intercepts.
    1. 5x + 3y = 10
    2. 6x – y = 12
  2. Graph the line and find the slope of:
    1. –8x + y = 10
    2. 3x – 8y = 4

Pronunciation Practice

Practice saying the following numbers:

(5, 2) (5, 6)
–4x + 7y = 19
5x – 8y = –33
x + 8y = 46
y = 3x + 8

Visit 2: Writing Equations

Bring your math textbook and visual chart to Visit #2.


This week you are leaning how to write an equation when given the slope and a point. Read the following information to your Speaking Partner:

Now that we can go from the equation of a line to finding points, getting the slope, and graphing the line, we are going to work on how to go backwards. It really isn’t as difficult as it seems. Since we can get the slope from an equation, we can certainly write an equation from the slope.

Example: Write an equation of the line that has slope m = 3/5 and goes through the point (5, 2).

There are two ways to do this. Remember, with standard form the slope is the negative of the first number over the second. In slope-intercept, the slope is right in front of the x when y is by itself.

StandardSlope-Intercept

Since the slope is 3/5, we know that an equation would have to be 3x – 5y = something, but what? Here is where we use the fact that (5, 2) has to work in the equation. If we stick in 5 for x and 2 for y, we get:

3(5) – 5(2) = ?

15 – 10 = 5

3x – 5y = 5

Since the slope is 3/5, we know that an equation would have to be y = 3/5(x) + b, but what is b? Here is where we use the fact that (5, 2) has to work in the equation. If we stick in 5 for x and 2 for y, we get:

2 = 3/5(5) + b

2 = 3 + b

–1 = b

Thus, our equation must be

y = 3/5(x) – 1

Do the following exercises with your Speaking Partner:

  • Write an equation of the line that has slope m = –4, and goes through the point (–3, 6). Put the answer in Standard Form.
  • Write an equation of the line that has slope m = 2/3, and goes through the point (4, 6). Put the answer in Slope-Intercept Form.

Visual Chart Chapter 4

Read the following material to your Speaking Partner:

This week your assignment is to make visual chart #4, which includes everything you have just learned in Chapter 4: Algebra. The information for this visual chart should include material from Lessons 10–12. Your visual chart should include information on charts and maps, lines and slope, and writing equations of lines. Divide up one side of the paper into sections. Write down everything you need to be able to do well on the exam this week.

Discussion Questions

  1. Show your visual chart to your Speaking Partner and describe the information you have included. If you not yet completed your visual chart, use the textbook to discuss the most important points from each chapter.
  2. Do you feel prepared this week for the exam?
  3. How well do you feel you know the material?

Pronunciation Practice

English Pronunciation: Beginning consonant clusters

Groups of consonants—or “consonant clusters”—must be pronounced closely together. Do not separate them with a vowel sound. Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following words. Then repeat the words.

Consonant Cluster

Consonant + Vowel
trade tirade
prayed parade
bloom balloon
claps collapse
sport support
plight polite
please peas

Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following consonant cluster words. Then repeat the words:

Clusters that begin with the letter “s”

  1. swim
  2. score
  3. skin
  4. small
  5. stay
  6. snake
  7. snail
  8. strong
  9. slow
  10. sweater

Clusters with the “r” or “l” sound as the second letter

  1. blink
  2. free
  3. grow
  4. cram
  5. blend
  6. plow
  7. train
  8. fly
  9. climb
  10. cry

Clusters with “w” as the second letter

  1. twelve
  2. twin
  3. swim
  4. swing
  5. swamp

Clusters with three consonants

  1. string
  2. sphere
  3. splendid
  4. through
  5. strap
  6. straw
  7. throw
  8. spray
  9. scrub
  10. school

Do the following activities with your Speaking Partner.

  • Choose three words from those listed above. Ask your Speaking Partner a question using those three words. Do this back and forth so that you have each asked and answered five questions.
  • Practice your pronunciation by repeating the following phrases several times:
We prayed the parade would proceed as planned.
The estate taxes are higher than the state taxes.
Sharon swims slowly through the swampy crossing.
